message.content: This question requires knowledge of the basic principles of light and shadows. When a source of light moves directly overhead of an object, the shadow of the object will decrease in size. This is because the angle at which the light hits the object becomes more perpendicular, resulting in a smaller shadow. Option (A) is incorrect because the object getting brighter would require the light source to become more intense, not just move overhead. Option (B) is incorrect because shadows do not spin. Option (D) is incorrect because light does not lean to one side; it simply moves in a straight path.

When a light source moves directly overhead of an object, the object's shadow will decrease in size. This is because the angle of the light hitting the object becomes more direct, causing the shadow to become shorter. Option (A) is incorrect because the brightness of the object is not directly related to the position of the light source. Option (B) is incorrect because shadows do not spin. Option (D) is incorrect because the light source itself does not lean to one side.
